message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Are Formal Methods Applicable To Machine Learning And Artificial Intelligence?
Paper Abstract: Formal approaches can provide strict correctness guarantees for the development of both hardware and software systems. In this work, we examine state-of-the-art formal methods for the verification and validation of machine learning systems in particular. We first provide a brief summary of existing formal approaches in general. After that, we report on formal methods developed for validating data preparation and training phases. Then, we go over the formal methods used for the verification of machine learning systems. At this level, we consider both partial and exhaustive techniques. In addition, we review research works dedicated to the verification of support vector machines and decision tree ensembles. Finally, we propose several potential future directions for formal verification of machine learning systems.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Links: [{"title":"Formal methods - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Formal_methods"},{"title":"Formal Methods Europe - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Formal_Methods_Europe"},{"title":"Category:Formal methods tools - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Formal_methods_tools"},{"title":"Category:Formal methods people - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Formal_methods_people"},{"title":"Category:Formal methods - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Formal_methods"},{"title":"Formal verification - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Formal_verification"},{"title":"Category:Formal methods terminology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Formal_methods_terminology"},{"title":"Category:Formal methods publications - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Formal_methods_publications"},{"title":"Category:Formal methods organizations - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Formal_methods_organizations"},{"title":"Talk:Formal methods - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Formal_methods"}]

## Formal Methods

In computer science, formal methods are mathematically rigorous techniques for the specification, development, analysis, and verification of software and hardware systems.(no content)The use of formal methods for software and hardware design is motivated by the expectation that mathematical analysis can contribute to the reliability and robustness of a design.

### Foundations and Techniques

Formal methods employ a variety of theoretical computer science fundamentals, including logic calculi, formal languages, automata theory, control theory, program semantics, type systems, and type theory.

### Applications

Formal methods can be applied at various points through the development process, used to give a formal description of the system to be developed, or to synthesize a program or verify the correctness of a system.(no content)By writing a specification, ambiguities in the informal requirements can be discovered and resolved.

### Real-World Usage

Formal methods are applied in different areas of hardware and software, including routers, Ethernet switches, routing protocols, security applications, and operating system microkernels such as seL4.(no content)IBM used ACL2, a theorem prover, in the AMD x86 processor development process, and Intel uses such methods to verify its hardware and firmware.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Formal methods are applied in different areas of hardware and software, including routers, Ethernet switches, routing protocols, security applications, and operating system microkernels such as seL4.(no content)IBM used ACL2, a theorem prover, in the AMD x86 processor development process, and Intel uses such methods to verify its hardware and firmware.

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about software verification:

## Definition and Purpose

Software verification is a discipline of software engineering, programming languages, and theory of computation whose goal is to assure that software satisfies the expected requirements.

## Verification vs. Validation

Software verification asks the question, "Are we building the product right?" (i.e., does the software conform to its specifications), while software validation asks the question, "Are we building the right product?" (i.e., does the software do what the user really requires).

## Two Fundamental Approaches

There are two fundamental approaches to verification: Dynamic verification (also known as experimentation, dynamic testing or testing), which is good for finding faults (software bugs), and static verification (also known as analysis or static testing), which is useful for proving the correctness of a program.

**Static Verification:** Static verification is the process of checking that software meets requirements by inspecting the code before it runs.

**Dynamic Verification:** Dynamic verification is performed during the execution of software, and dynamically checks its behavior; it is commonly known as the Test phase.

## Formal Verification

In computer science, formal methods are mathematically rigorous techniques for the specification, development, analysis, and verification of software and hardware systems. The use of formal methods for software and hardware design is motivated by the expectation that performing appropriate mathematical analysis can contribute to the reliability and robustness of a design.

## Machine Learning - Web Search Results

I've performed a web search for "Machine Learning" and found comprehensive information. Here are the key findings:

### Definition and Overview

Machine learning (ML) is a field of study in artificial intelligence concerned with the development and study of statistical algorithms that can learn from data and generalise to unseen data, and thus perform tasks without explicit instructions.

### Applications

ML finds application in many fields, including natural language processing, computer vision, speech recognition, email filtering, agriculture, and medicine.

### Learning Paradigms

Machine learning is commonly separated into three main learning paradigms, supervised learning, unsupervised learning and reinforcement learning.

### Historical Development

The term machine learning was coined in 1959 by Arthur Samuel, an IBM employee and pioneer in the field of computer gaming and artificial intelligence.(no content)The earliest machine learning program was introduced in the 1950s when Arthur Samuel invented a computer program that calculated the winning chance in checkers for each side.

### Modern Advances

Within a subdiscipline in machine learning, advances in the field of deep learning have allowed neural networks, a class of statistical algorithms, to surpass many previous machine learning approaches in performance.

The search results provide a wealth of information about machine learning fundamentals, neural networks, and the field's historical development.

Hetzel - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_C._Hetzel"},{"title":"Verification and validation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Verification_and_validation"},{"title":"Sanity check - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sanity_check"}]

## Software Validation Testing

Based on the search results, here's what you need to know about software validation testing:

### Definition

Software validation is the process of checking that a software system meets specifications and requirements so that it fulfills its intended purpose.(no content)It may also be referred to as software quality control.

### Key Purpose

Software validation checks that the software product satisfies or fits the intended use (high-level checking), i.e., the software meets the user requirements, not as specification artifacts or as needs of those who will operate the software only; but, as the needs of all the stakeholders (such as users, operators, administrators, managers, investors, etc.).

A common way to express this difference is: Software validation ensures that "you built the right thing" and confirms that the product, as provided, fulfills the intended use and goals of the stakeholders.

### Validation Approaches

There are two ways to perform software validation: internal and external.(no content)During internal software validation, it is assumed that the goals of the stakeholders were correctly understood and that they were expressed in the requirement artifacts precisely and comprehensively. If the software meets the requirement specification, it has been internally validated.(no content)External validation happens when it is performed by asking the stakeholders if the software meets their needs.

### Validation vs. Verification

It's important to note that validation differs from verification. Software verification ensures that the output of each phase of the software development process effectively carries out what its corresponding input artifact specifies (requirement -> design -> software product), while software validation ensures that the software product meets the needs of all the stakeholders.

Artificial intelligence is the capability of computational systems to perform tasks typically associated with human intelligence, such as learning, reasoning, problem-solving, perception, and decision-making.

### Core Goals and Techniques
The traditional goals of AI research include learning, reasoning, knowledge representation, planning, natural language processing, perception, and support for robotics.(no content)To reach these goals, AI researchers have adapted and integrated a wide range of techniques, including search and mathematical optimization, formal logic, artificial neural networks, and methods based on statistics, operations research, and economics.

### Historical Development
Artificial intelligence was founded as an academic discipline in 1956, and the field went through multiple cycles of optimism throughout its history, followed by periods of disappointment and loss of funding, known as AI winters.

### Artificial General Intelligence (AGI)
Artificial general intelligence (AGI)—sometimes called human‑level intelligence AI—is a type of artificial intelligence that would match or surpass human capabilities across virtually all cognitive tasks.(no content)Some companies, such as OpenAI, Google DeepMind and Meta, aim to create artificial general intelligence (AGI) – AI that can complete virtually any cognitive task at least as well as a human.

### Applications
Artificial intelligence has been used in applications throughout industry and academia. These applications span numerous fields, from generative artificial intelligence (Generative AI, or GenAI) that uses generative models to generate text, images, videos, audio, software code or other forms of data, to military, healthcare, and creative fields.

Web search results for query: "Support Vector Machine"

Links: [{"title":"Support vector machine - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Support_vector_machine"},{"title":"Least-squares support vector machine - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Least-squares_support_vector_machine"},{"title":"Regularization perspectives on support vector machines - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Regularization_perspectives_on_support_vector_machines"},{"title":"Category:Support vector machines - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Support_vector_machines"},{"title":"Multimodal learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multimodal_learning"}]

I've completed a web search for "Support Vector Machine". Here's what I found:

## Overview

Support Vector Machines (SVMs, also known as support vector networks) are supervised max-margin models with associated learning algorithms that analyze data for classification and regression analysis.

## Key Concept

A support vector machine constructs a hyperplane or set of hyperplanes in a high or infinite-dimensional space, which can be used for classification, regression, or other tasks like outlier detection. More specifically, the best hyperplane is the one that represents the largest separation, or margin, between the two classes, maximizing the distance from it to the nearest data point on each side.

## History

The original SVM algorithm was invented by Vladimir N. Vapnik and Alexey Ya. Chervonenkis in 1964.(no content)In 1992, Bernhard Boser, Isabelle Guyon and Vladimir Vapnik suggested a way to create nonlinear classifiers by applying the kernel trick to maximum-margin hyperplanes.

## Applications

SVMs have been applied to many domains, including:
- Text and hypertext categorization
- Classification of images
- Hand-written character recognition
- Protein classification with up to 90% accuracy

Web search results for query: "Decision Tree Ensemble"

Links: [{"title":"Decision tree learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Decision_tree_learning"},{"title":"Ensemble learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ensemble_learning"},{"title":"Random forest - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Random_forest"},{"title":"Decision tree - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Decision_tree"},{"title":"Bootstrap aggregating - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bootstrap_aggregating"},{"title":"Gradient boosting - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gradient_boosting"},{"title":"Decision stump - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Decision_stump"},{"title":"Decision tree model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Decision_tree_model"},{"title":"Information gain (decision tree) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Information_gain_(decision_tree)"},{"title":"Logistic model tree - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Logistic_model_tree"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about Decision Tree Ensembles:

## Overview

Decision Tree Ensembles are ensemble methods that construct more than one decision tree. They represent a powerful approach to improve prediction accuracy and stability by combining multiple decision trees.

## Main Types of Decision Tree Ensembles

**Bootstrap Aggregating (Bagging):**
Bootstrap aggregated (or bagged) decision trees build multiple decision trees by repeatedly resampling training data with replacement, and voting the trees for a consensus prediction. This ensemble meta-algorithm is designed to improve the stability and accuracy of ML classification and regression algorithms, and also reduces variance and overfitting.

**Boosting:**
Boosted trees incrementally build an ensemble by training each new instance to emphasize the training instances previously mis-modeled, with a typical example being AdaBoost.

**Random Forests:**
Random forests is an ensemble learning method for classification, regression and other tasks that works by creating a multitude of decision trees during training. Random forests represent an extension of bagging.

**Gradient Boosted Trees:**
When a decision tree is the weak learner, the resulting algorithm is called gradient-boosted trees; it usually outperforms random forest.

## How They Work

Inference is done by voting of predictions of ensemble members, called aggregation, where individual classifications are aggregated and an overall classification is derived.

## Key Advantages

Ensembles tend to yield better results when there is a significant diversity among the models, and many ensemble methods therefore seek to promote diversity among the models they combine.
